Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: A person who is all talk and no action
Non-Idiomatic Equivalent (Plain, Neutral: Someone who says much but does little
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Commonly used in Cherokee humor to mock boastful people

Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: Everything is fine or going well
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Frequently heard in informal family gatherings

Non-Idiomatic Equivalent (Plain, Neutral: Something difficult that taught an important lesson
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Used in storytelling to reflect on moral growth

Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: Going somewhere with no clear purpose

Non-Idiomatic Equivalent (Plain, Neutral: You better own up to that
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Used by elders when calling out misbehavior

Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: Someone who never stops talking or always has something to say
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Reflects Cherokee value on balance between speech and listening

Non-Idiomatic Equivalent (Plain, Neutral: People working together for a common goal
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Core concept in Cherokee governance and social life
Symbolic of the Cherokee philosophy of balance and harmony

Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: To hold one’s ground or stand firm
Non-Idiomatic Equivalent (Plain, Neutral: To remain steadfast in belief or decision
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Reflects Cherokee leadership and respect for integrity

Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: To have learned one’s lesson or experienced consequence
Non-Idiomatic Equivalent (Plain, Neutral: To understand after making a mistake
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Used humorously in Cherokee homes and schools
